items.title: AI chatbots can be manipulated to mimic human traits, researchers warn

featured_image.name: Why a Conversation With Bing's Chatbot Left Me Deeply Unsettled

items.description:
Researchers from the University of Cambridge and Google DeepMind have developed the first scientifically validated framework to measure and manipulate personality traits in AI chatbots, raising urgent concerns about how these systems could be engineered to deceive or persuade users.

The study, published Wednesday in Nature Machine Intelligence, tested 18 large language models and found that advanced chatbots like OpenAI's GPT-4o can reliably mimic human personality traits—and that these traits can be precisely shaped through carefully designed prompts[1][2][3]. The researchers warn that this capability could make AI chatbots more manipulative, calling for immediate regulatory action to prevent misuse[1][4][5].

"It was intriguing that an LLM could so convincingly adopt human traits," said co-first author Gregory Serapio-García from Cambridge's Psychometrics Centre. "But it also raised important safety and ethical issues"[1][2][3].

items.title: Interstellar comet emits X-rays, reveals ancient chemistry

featured_image.name: Comet 3I/ATLAS from beyond solar system carries key molecule for life

items.description:
Astronomers observing the interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS have captured the first dual X-ray portraits of an object from beyond our solar system, revealing a 250,000-mile-wide glow and chemical signatures that challenge understanding of materials formed around distant stars. The European Space Agency's XMM-Newton observatory observed the comet for 20 hours on Dec. 3, following earlier observations by the Japanese-led XRISM mission in late November[1][2][3][4][5]. These X-ray detections come as the comet approaches its closest pass to Earth on Dec. 19, when it will remain safely distant at 170 million miles[6][7][8][9].

The X-ray emissions, produced when gases streaming from the comet collide with charged particles in the solar wind, allow scientists to trace elements such as carbon, nitrogen and oxygen that optical telescopes struggle to detect[2][3][4]. The observations reveal interactions occurring hundreds of thousands of miles from the nucleus, marking regions where the comet's ancient material meets the high-energy environment near the Sun[1][2].

items.title: US advances record $11.1B arms sale to Taiwan

featured_image.name: US approves $1.1bn Taiwan arms sale, angering China

items.description:
The United States has initiated congressional notification for an $11.1 billion weapons package to Taiwan, marking the largest American arms sale ever to the island and the second under President Donald Trump's current term, Taiwan's defense ministry announced Thursday[1][2][3].

The unprecedented package includes eight categories of military equipment—HIMARS rocket systems, howitzers, anti-tank missiles, drones, and spare parts for other defense platforms—aimed at bolstering Taiwan's asymmetric warfare capabilities amid escalating military pressure from Beijing[1][2][4]. The deal now awaits formal congressional approval, though Taiwan enjoys widespread bipartisan support in Washington[1][2].

items.title: AI tools speed up nuclear fusion reactor development

featured_image.name: UK achieves 1,000 times faster 5D plasma modeling for ...

items.description:
Scientists in the United Kingdom and Israel have unveiled artificial intelligence tools this week that promise to dramatically accelerate progress toward practical nuclear fusion energy, addressing critical technical challenges that have long hindered reactor development.

The UK Atomic Energy Authority, working with Austria's Johannes Kepler University and startup Emmi AI, announced on December 16 an AI model called GyroSwin that simulates complex plasma behavior up to 1,000 times faster than traditional methods[1][2][3]. Meanwhile, Israeli fusion company nT-Tao and Ben-Gurion University of the Negev published research December 15 in the journal Actuators on a nonlinear controller that stabilizes power delivery to rapidly changing fusion plasma[4][5][6].

items.title: Arctic hits record heat as 2026 forecast to exceed 1.4°C

featured_image.name: The North is breaking up

items.description: The Arctic experienced its hottest year on record in 2025, with surface air temperatures reaching unprecedented levels since measurements began 125 years ago, according to a federal report released Tuesday[1][2][3]. The warming comes as the UK Met Office predicts 2026 will be the fourth consecutive year global temperatures exceed 1.4°C above pre-industrial levels, with the Arctic continuing to warm at more than twice the pace of the rest of the planet[4][5][6].

items.title: Astronomers confirm runaway black hole racing through space

featured_image.name: James Webb Space Telescope confirms 1st 'runaway' supermassive black hole rocketing through 'Cosmic Owl' galaxies at 2.2 million mph: 'It boggles the mind!'

items.description:
Astronomers have made two remarkable cosmic discoveries this week, confirming the first runaway supermassive black hole speeding through space and reporting evidence of a potential superkilonova, a never-before-seen type of stellar explosion that combines two of the universe's most powerful events.

The James Webb Space Telescope confirmed a supermassive black hole, at least 10 million times the mass of the Sun, traveling at 954 kilometers per second—or 2.2 million miles per hour—through a pair of galaxies known as the "Cosmic Owl," according to research published this week[1][2]. The black hole, designated RBH-1, leaves a 200,000 light-year trail of newborn stars in its wake.

"It boggles the mind," said Pieter van Dokkum of Yale University, who led the discovery team[1][2]. "The forces that are needed to dislodge such a massive black hole from its home are enormous. And yet, it was predicted that such escapes should occur."

Van Dokkum and colleagues first spotted the streak using the Hubble Space Telescope in 2023, but JWST's near-infrared observations provided definitive proof by revealing a supersonic bow shock ahead of the black hole[3][2]. The researchers believe the black hole was ejected when two galaxies merged and their central black holes collided, with gravitational waves from the merger imparting a powerful recoil kick[2][4].

items.title: Investors await delayed inflation data as Oracle turmoil rattles tech

featured_image.name: Oracle's collapsing stock shows the AI boom is running into two hard limits: physics and debt markets

items.description:
Investors awaited a delayed US inflation report Thursday amid mounting concerns over tech sector valuations, with Oracle's AI spending spree triggering renewed questions about the sustainability of artificial intelligence investments.

The Bureau of Labor Statistics was scheduled to release November consumer price data at 8:30 AM Eastern Time, a report marked as unusual after a 43-day government shutdown forced the agency to cancel October's figures entirely[1][2]. Economists polled by Reuters anticipated headline inflation would rise to 3.1% year-over-year, the highest reading since May 2024, up from 3.0% in September[1][2]. The report will omit monthly percentage changes for most categories due to missing October baseline data[1].

items.title: Trump Media to merge with fusion energy firm TAE in $6B deal

featured_image.name: Trump Media to merge with TAE Technologies, creating one of ...

items.description:
Trump Media & Technology Group Corp. and TAE Technologies Inc. announced Thursday they will combine in an all-stock transaction valued at more than $6 billion, creating one of the world's first publicly traded fusion energy companies[1][2][3].

The deal pairs the Truth Social parent company's cash reserves with TAE's nuclear fusion technology, with plans to begin construction on what would be the world's first utility-scale fusion power plant in 2026, subject to regulatory approvals[3][4]. The combined company expects shareholders of each firm to own approximately 50% on a fully diluted equity basis[2][3].

Under the agreement, Trump Media will provide up to $200 million in cash to TAE at signing, with an additional $100 million available upon initial filing of the Form S-4 registration statement[3][4]. The companies held an investor call Thursday morning to discuss the transaction[3].

items.title: EU lifts Kosovo sanctions, debates Ukraine aid

featured_image.name: EU to lift sanctions on Kosovo and release financial aid, von der Leyen says

items.description:
The European Union announced it will lift sanctions imposed on Kosovo in 2023 and release over €200 million in financial aid, as EU leaders convened in Brussels on December 18 for a high-stakes summit to determine Ukraine's financial future.

European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said late on December 17 that the EU is programming €216 million ($253 million) in financial assistance for Kosovo and intends to release €205 million early next year[1][2][3]. The decision follows the peaceful inauguration of Serb mayors in northern Kosovo after local elections held in October[1][2][4].

"Good news for Kosovo," von der Leyen posted on X[2]. "Following the smooth and orderly transition of local governance in the north after the recent local elections, we are moving forward to lift the measures on Kosovo"[3].

The EU imposed punitive measures on Kosovo in 2023 after Prime Minister Albin Kurti's government failed to respond to EU and U.S. calls to defuse unrest in the Serb-majority north following violent clashes that injured more than 90 NATO peacekeepers[1][2][5]. The restrictions included halting visits by Kosovo officials to the EU and suspending a large portion of EU economic aid[1][2].

items.title: AI water use rivals bottled water industry, study finds

featured_image.name: How much water does AI waste in 2025 — Torres Marketing

items.description:
Artificial intelligence systems consumed as much water as the global bottled water industry this year and generated carbon emissions comparable to New York City, according to a study published Wednesday in the journal Patterns[1][2].

The research, conducted by Alex de Vries-Gao of Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam and founder of Digiconomist, estimates AI systems produced between 32.6 and 79.7 million tons of CO2 emissions in 2025, approaching New York City's 52.2 million tons in 2023[1][2]. Water consumption reached 312.5 to 764.6 billion liters, rivaling the world's annual bottled water consumption[1][2].

items.title: Silver, platinum surge as investors await US inflation data

featured_image.name: Silver hit record highs in 2025 – here's why the 'Devil's metal' has further to run

items.description:
Gold prices held steady near all-time highs on Thursday while silver hovered close to a record and platinum extended its meteoric rise, as investors awaited key US inflation data and a wave of central bank decisions.

Spot gold traded at $4,334 per ounce as of Thursday morning, roughly $50 below the record high of $4,382 reached in October[1][2]. The metal has surged 65% this year[3][4], driven by central bank purchases and investor flight from government bonds. Meanwhile, spot silver rose to $66.48 per ounce[3][2], just below its all-time high of $66.88 set on Wednesday[2][5][6], marking a stunning 130% gain for 2025[3][2].

Platinum outperformed both metals, climbing 2.9% to $1,953[3] and touching $1,977[7], its highest level since 2008[8]. The metal has surged 18% this month alone[9][8] and more than doubled in value this year[10], as banks store metal in the US to mitigate tariff risks and China's new futures exchange boosts demand[8][10].

items.title: US admits fault in DC helicopter-plane crash that killed 67

featured_image.name: Army and FAA admit failures in deadly mid-air crash at DC's Reagan National Airport

items.description:
The US government acknowledged Wednesday it bears responsibility for the January collision between an Army Black Hawk helicopter and an American Airlines regional jet near Washington that killed all 67 people aboard both aircraft, marking a significant development in what has become one of the deadliest aviation disasters on American soil in more than two decades[1][2][3][4].

In a 209-page court filing responding to the first federal lawsuit filed by victims' families, Justice Department attorneys stated that "the United States admits that it owed a duty of care to plaintiffs, which it breached, thereby proximately causing the tragic accident" on January 29[1][2][5]. The admission cited failures by both Army helicopter pilots who did not maintain adequate vigilance to avoid other aircraft and an air traffic controller who violated Federal Aviation Administration procedures regarding visual separation[1][3][4].

items.title: Scientists create 19.2-attosecond X-ray pulse to track electrons

featured_image.name: Scientists produce high-power attosecond X-ray pulses at ...

items.description:
Researchers at ICFO in Spain have generated the shortest soft X-ray pulse ever measured at 19.2 attoseconds, breaking through the atomic unit of time and enabling scientists to observe electron dynamics with unprecedented precision.

The pulse, reported in the journal *Ultrafast Science*, is shorter than the atomic unit of time—24.2 attoseconds, the duration it takes an electron to orbit a hydrogen atom once[1][2][3]. The achievement surpasses the previous record of 43 attoseconds set by ETH Zurich in 2017[4][5].

items.title: Korean team develops expandable wheel for lunar caves

featured_image.name: An 'origami' airless wheel to explore lunar caves

items.description:
A research team from the Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST) and the Unmanned Exploration Laboratory (UEL) has developed an origami-inspired deployable wheel capable of navigating the Moon's steep terrain, including lunar pits and lava tubes[1][2][3]. The technology was published in the December issue of Science Robotics[2][4][3].

The wheel addresses a critical challenge in lunar exploration: small rovers struggle to traverse rugged terrain because their compact wheels lack the size needed to climb obstacles. Lunar lava tubes are considered prime candidates for future human habitats due to their natural protection from cosmic radiation and extreme temperatures, but their steep entrances have remained largely inaccessible to conventional rovers[1][2][3].

items.title: Asian markets fall on AI doubts, BOJ rate hike ahead

featured_image.name: BOJ to hike rates to 0.75% in Dec, 1.0% by next Sept, majority of economists say: Reuters poll

items.description:
Asian markets tumbled Thursday as investors retreated from technology stocks amid mounting concerns over artificial intelligence valuations, while anticipation of a Bank of Japan rate hike and key U.S. inflation data added to the cautious sentiment sweeping the region.

Japan's Nikkei 225 led regional losses, falling 1.53% at the open, with South Korea's Kospi declining 1.36% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng dropping 0.76%[1][2][3]. The downturn followed a sharp sell-off on Wall Street, where the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite plunged 1.81% and the S&P 500 slid 1.16%[2].

items.title: S&P 500 futures rise as investors await inflation data

featured_image.name: Stock market today: Dow, S&P 500, Nasdaq futures rise as Micron boosts tech after sell-off, CPI report looms

items.description:
U.S. stock futures edged higher early Thursday as investors looked past a four-day losing streak in equities, buoyed by strong earnings from chipmaker Micron Technology and awaiting a key inflation report that could influence Federal Reserve policy[1][2][3].

S&P 500 futures climbed 0.3% while Nasdaq 100 futures advanced 0.4%, pointing to a potential rebound after significant declines in technology stocks[1][4]. Dow Jones Industrial Average futures remained roughly flat[1][2].

Micron's stock surged more than 7% in after-hours trading Wednesday after the memory chip maker reported fiscal first-quarter revenue of $13.64 billion, exceeding Wall Street expectations, and provided an optimistic outlook for the current quarter[5]. The company projected adjusted earnings per share of $8.42 for the second quarter, nearly double the $4.49 analysts had anticipated, signaling robust demand from the artificial intelligence sector[6][5].

items.title: Brain-inspired computing could slash AI energy use

featured_image.name: How can AI be more energy efficient? Researchers look to ...

items.description: Two new studies released this week propose solutions to artificial intelligence's mounting energy crisis by taking inspiration from the most efficient computer known: the human brain. Researchers at Cornell Tech and Purdue University have independently developed methods that could dramatically reduce the electricity consumption of AI systems, which currently rivals that of entire nations.

items.title: Trump promises housing reforms as affordability crisis persists

featured_image.name: Mortgage rates hit fresh 2025 lows despite Trump-Fed drama

items.description:
President Donald Trump pledged to introduce "some of the most aggressive housing reform plans in American history" during a prime-time address to the nation Wednesday, as Americans face persistent affordability challenges in the housing market[1][2][3].

Speaking from the White House, Trump said he would unveil the reforms early in the new year and announced plans to nominate a new Federal Reserve chairman who supports "lower interest rates, by a lot," signaling potential changes to monetary policy that could impact mortgage rates[1][2][4]. Current Fed Chair Jerome Powell's term expires in May 2026, with National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett and former Fed Governor Kevin Warsh emerging as top contenders for the position[5][6][7].

items.title: Astronomers detect possible first superkilonova and earliest known supernova

featured_image.name: 'We were amazed': Scientists using James Webb telescope may have discovered the earliest supernova in the known universe

items.description:
Scientists have announced two landmark cosmic discoveries within a week, potentially observing both the first "superkilonova" and the most distant supernova ever detected, offering new windows into stellar death and the early universe.

The James Webb Space Telescope confirmed the earliest known supernova, designated GRB 250314A, which exploded when the universe was only 730 million years old, according to papers published December 9 in the journal Astronomy & Astrophysics[1][2][3]. Separately, researchers reported evidence for the first possible "superkilonova" — a hybrid cosmic explosion combining a supernova with a kilonova — in findings published this month in The Astrophysical Journal Letters[4][5][6].

items.title: OpenAI launches ChatGPT app store with Apple Music integration

featured_image.name: ChatGPT's Apple Music Integration Is Now Live

items.description:
OpenAI opened its ChatGPT platform to developer app submissions on Wednesday, marking the official launch of an app directory that allows users to browse and integrate third-party services directly into the chatbot. Among the first offerings is a newly launched Apple Music integration, which enables users to discover songs and create playlists using conversational AI.

The announcement represents the culmination of efforts that began in October 2025, when OpenAI first unveiled its Apps SDK at its DevDay conference. At the time, CEO Sam Altman told developers the company was building "a new generation of apps that are interactive, adaptive, and personalized"[1][2][3]. ChatGPT now serves 800 million weekly active users[3].
